questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of burn injuries that she sustained after stumbling into a bonfire 1 hour ago. The patient has severe pain in her left leg and torso, and minimal pain in her right arm. She does not smoke cigarettes. She takes no medications. She is tearful and in moderate distress. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 118/65 mm Hg. Her pulse oximetry is 98% on room air. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There are two tender, blanchable erythemas without blisters over a 5 x 6-cm area of the left abdomen and a 3 x 2-cm area of the left anterior thigh. There is also an area of white, leathery skin and tissue necrosis encircling the right upper extremity just proximal to the elbow, which is dry and nontender. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with no ST or T wave changes. Administration of intravenous fluids is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Monitoring of peripheral pulses and capillary filling

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serial arterial blood gas analysis is indicated in burn patients if inhalation injury is suspected. Such patients would include those presenting with dyspnea, coughing, wheezing, patients trapped in confined spaces, or who lose consciousness in the presence of heavy smoke. The patient is stable and breathing normally, and did not experience any of these situations.

B) INCORRECT:

A soft-tissue ultrasound is indicated for the evaluation of lymph nodes and conditions, such as cellulitis and abscess, but it is not useful for the diagnosis of compartment syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Ampicillin (or any other systemic antibiotic) is currently not recommended for prophylaxis of infections in burn patients because of a lack of supporting evidence. Although systemic antibiotics have a role in the treatment of burn wound infections, the patient was brought in just after the burn occurred; a potential infection would not have had time to develop yet.

D) CORRECT:

Regular monitoring of peripheral pulses and capillary filling is indicated in this patient because of her risk for distal ischemia. Her circumferential burn may impair blood flow to the limb secondary to a loss of skin elasticity (due to a developing eschar) or result in compartment syndrome (caused by an accumulation of fluids) during the healing process.

E) INCORRECT:

Severely burned patients are at risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) because the extensive tissue damage may lead to a massive release of inflammatory mediators. A chest x-ray is therefore indicated in burn patients who present with symptoms of ARDS (e.g., dyspnea, tachypnea, low oxygen saturation, cyanosis). However, this is not the case for this patient, who is hemodynamically stable and breathing normally.
questions.hint: This patient has a 3rd degree (full-thickness) circumferential burn on her right upper extremity, as indicated by the encircling white, leathery skin and necrosis without feeling. Such burns may lead to distal ischemia and compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Three hours later, the patient is reassessed. Her right arm is put in an elevated position and a physical examination of the extremity is performed. The examination reveals reduced capillary return and peripheral pallor. Pulse oximetry of her right index finger on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fasciotomy is the treatment of choice for acute compartment syndrome (ACS). While this woman shows signs of compromised distal perfusion (reduced capillary refill, pallor, and peripheral O2 saturation of 84%) that could also be due to developing ACS, the vascular compromise is more likely caused by the circumferential eschar itself. Furthermore, ACS is generally associated with severe pain, often out of proportion to the extent of the injury. This patient only has minimal pain in her right arm, resulting from the third-degree burn that has destroyed the cutaneous nerves. Sensation of the deeper layers, including the muscle compartments, however, should still be intact.

B) INCORRECT:

Amputation of the extremity may be indicated in patients with severe fourth-degree burns. It is also the last resort in patients with acute compartment syndrome and/or acute limb ischemia who present very late (3–5 days) after onset with a nonviable limb. This woman has a third-degree burn, and although her findings suggest beginning vascular compromise (reduced capillary refill, pallor, and a peripheral O2 saturation of 84%), less radical measures are indicated first to restore blood flow.

C) INCORRECT:

A split-thickness skin graft is a definitive treatment option for third-degree burns, such as the wound on this patient's right arm. However, definitive management is only considered after all immediate measures have been carried out. This patient presents acutely with signs of vascular compromise, as indicated by the reduced capillary refill; blood flow needs to be restored as soon as possible to prevent compartment syndrome and acute limb ischemia.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has extensive burns on her arm, leg, and torso. Adequate fluid resuscitation is an important part of the immediate measures for severe burn wounds to counter the fluid loss/shift and to prevent dehydration and associated complications such as acute kidney injury and shock. The circumferential edema that results from the burn eschar and causes compromised perfusion of her arm is likely exacerbated by fluid replacement, but decreasing the rate of IV fluids is not the appropriate therapeutic measure to resolve the vascular compromise.

E) CORRECT:

Escharotomy is the treatment of choice for third-degree (full-thickness) circumferential burns leading to impaired perfusion of the extremity, such as the burn on this patient's right arm. Reduced capillary return, peripheral pallor, and markedly reduced oxygen saturation indicate vascular compromise secondary to the developing eschar and the associated constriction caused by the edematous, unyielding skin. If perfusion is not restored in a timely manner, compartment syndrome and acute limb ischemia may result.
Image Description:

Photograph of the chest and right shoulder

The skin appears dry, leathery, and black, indicating tissue necrosis (eschar). There is no visible blistering.

These features are characteristic of a third-degree burn, which affects all the layers of the skin (i.e., the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue).
questions.hint: This patient's circumferential burn can cut off blood supply to the extremity.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man comes to the emergency department 6 hours after spilling boiling oil on his torso. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He works as an assistant chef. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows a leathery, dry area of skin with clearly defined borders on his upper chest that covers 10% of his body's surface area. The affected area of the skin has no sensation to light touch, temperature, or pinprick; it does not blanch with pressure. The underlying muscles, fat, and fascia appear to be intact. The patient has normal respiratory effort and all distal pulses are intact. After stabilization and resuscitation in the emergency department, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Topical antibiotics, followed by application of sterile dressings
Allow burn to heal for three months, followed by debridement of necrotic tissue
Early excision of necrotic tissue, followed by split-thickness skin graft
Immediate escharotomy, followed by transfer to the burn unit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids should not be used to treat burns of any degree because they result in delayed wound healing and further increase the risk of bacterial infection in the wound.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics, followed by the application of sterile dressings, are the treatment of choice for second-degree burns. This patient has third-degree burns, for which these interventions alone are insufficient; a more aggressive form of management is indicated to treat the burnt, necrotic tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

In the past, delayed debridement was the treatment of choice for patients with third-degree burns. Delayed debridement is no longer recommended as it is associated with an increase in mortality, length of hospital stay, cost of care, and the need for reconstruction surgery. A more immediate treatment approach is indicated for this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Early debridement of necrotic tissue is the treatment of choice for third-degree burns. A split-thickness skin graft taken from an undamaged donor site is then used to cover the defect. Rarely, a full-thickness graft or a skin flap may be used, especially if functionally or cosmetically important regions such as the digits or the face are involved. Early debridement and wound closure has been shown to decrease the risk of infections and improve overall outcomes.

E) INCORRECT:

A transfer to a specialized burn unit is indicated for any third-degree burn, no matter the extent of the affected surface area. In a patient with burns involving the thorax, escharotomy is only indicated for circumferential burns that cause respiratory distress (e.g., hypoventilation, increased airway pressures, decreased oxygen saturation). This patient has a normal respiratory effort, and the burns involve just one side of the thorax, the upper chest, which does not qualify as a circumferential burn.
questions.hint: Third-degree burns have full-thickness involvement, turn leathery and nonelastic, and form a thick band upon drying called an eschar. They are painless and do not blanch on applying pressure.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman is brought into the emergency room by emergency medical services 30 minutes after a kitchen fire during which she sustained burns to the face. On arrival, she is distressed but awake and alert; she is able to speak normally. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.3°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Breath sounds are normal. There is erythema with ruptured and unruptured blistering visible over the forehead, cheeks, and around the eyes, all of which are minimally tender. There is no erythema, edema, or blistering apparent around or in the patient's mouth. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Following cleaning and debridement of the burned areas, which of the following is the best management for this patient's burns?

choices.text: Topical silver sulfadiazine cream with nonadherent dressing
Topical bacitracin ointment with nonadherent dressing
Topical povidone-iodine ointment with nonadherent dressing
IV cephalosporin antibiotic with nonadherent dressing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical silver sulfadiazine cream with nonadherent dressing is generally appropriate for the management of second-degree burns. However, this patient's burns are periorbital, and silver sulfadiazine is toxic to the eyes.

B) CORRECT:

Topical bacitracin ointment with nonadherent dressing is appropriate for the management of second-degree burns affecting the periorbital area. Some topical antimicrobial agents that are typically used for the management of burns (e.g., silver sulfadiazine) are toxic to the eyes and should be avoided in patients with periorbital burns.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical povidone-iodine ointment with nonadherent dressing is generally appropriate for the management of second-degree burns. However, this patient's burns are periorbital and povidone-iodine ointment is toxic to the eyes.

D) INCORRECT:

A nonadherent dressing is indicated in this patient's case. However, systemic antibiotics are only administered in burn treatment when signs of burn wound infection or sepsis are present.

E) INCORRECT:

Because this patient has a second-degree burn, nonadherent dressings alone are not sufficient. An antimicrobial agent is also indicated.
questions.hint: This patient has facial burns that must be managed carefully to avoid damage to the eyes.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of pain and redness on his back for 2 days. He returned yesterday from a vacation to East Africa with his parents, where he took multiple rides on hot air balloons. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a tender, nonpruritic, erythematous rash with edema covering the extensor surface of both forearms, the shoulders, and the upper back, with small patches of skin exfoliation. The rash becomes pale when pressed and then rapidly regains color. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wound dressing is indicated for open burns (i.e., partial-thickness or full-thickness burns) because they entail damage to the entire epidermal layer. In these cases, the ability of the skin to retain fluid is lost, making it prone to drying, which impairs wound healing and increases the risk of dehydration. This patient has no open burns, so dressing is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous fluid resuscitation is indicated for burns that are partial-thickness or deeper (2nd-degree burns to 4th-degree burns), and generally only when the total body surface area involved is ≥ 20%, as these burns cause excessive fluid loss that cannot be sufficiently replaced orally. This patient has 1st-degree burns, in which the epidermis is intact and prevents fluid loss, and has no signs of hypovolemia (normotensive and normal heart rate). Therefore, intravenous fluid resuscitation is unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Lidocaine cream can potentially irritate damaged skin and should therefore generally be avoided in the management of sunburns.

D) INCORRECT:

Debridement is indicated when the dermis is exposed (i.e., partial-thickness or full-thickness burns) to aid in wound healing. This patient has 1st-degree burns, which do not expose the dermis; debridement is unnecessary. In addition, because the dermis is intact, the burn will resolve on its own without scarring.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical antimicrobial prophylaxis (e.g., mupirocin) is indicated for deep partial-thickness burns and full-thickness burns. This patient has a 1st-degree burn (with an intact epidermal barrier that protects against infection), which does not require antimicrobial prophylaxis.

F) CORRECT:

Topical moisturizers, such as those that contain aloe vera or calamine, are recommended to relieve symptoms of 1st-degree burns. These burns only involve the superficial epidermis and spare the dermis. The keratin barrier thus remains intact, retaining fluid and barring microbial entry. For this reason, no antimicrobial prophylaxis, fluid support, or debridement is necessary. Oral NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) may be given for pain and inflammation associated with sunburns. Important preventative measures to avoid sunburns include avoidance of direct sunlight (especially during midday), protective clothing, and application of broad-spectrum sunscreens (with sun protective factor ≥ 30) 15–30 minutes prior to sun exposure. Sunscreen should be reapplied every 2 hours and after water exposure.
Image Description:

Upper body of a patient with moderate sunburn

Patches of erythema are visible across the areas of skin that were most exposed to the sun. The absence of blisters distinguishes this presentation from a second-degree burn (partial-thickness burn).

Sunburn most commonly manifests as a first-degree burn, but higher-degree burns are possible with prolonged sun exposure.
questions.hint: A tender, erythematous, and edematous rash after sun exposure that blanches with pressure and refills rapidly is indicative of a superficial (1st-degree) sunburn. Approximately 15–20% of the surface area of this patient's body is involved.

questions.text: A 28-year-old research assistant is brought to the emergency department for severe chemical burns 30 minutes after accidentally spilling hydrochloric acid on himself. The burns cover both hands and forearms. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 108/82 mm Hg. Initial stabilization and resuscitation is begun, including respiratory support, fluid resuscitation, and cardiovascular stabilization. The burned skin is irrigated with saline water to remove the chemical agent. Which of the following is the most appropriate method to verify adequate fluid infusion in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tachycardia is a common early sign of hypovolemia. However, the heart rate is of minimal utility in assessing fluid resuscitation because even adequately resuscitated burn patients may be mildly tachycardic, likely due to stress hormone (e.g., catecholamine) release.

B) INCORRECT:

The Parkland formula is a tool commonly used to estimate fluid requirements during the first 24 hours of care in burn patients. While this is a good tool for estimating this patient's initial fluid requirements, it is merely an estimate. Another method can more accurately verify if fluid resuscitation is adequate. In addition, because of studies demonstrating serious complications from over-resuscitation (e.g., pleural effusions, compartment syndrome), the ATLS and American Burn Association now recommend only giving half of the fluid resuscitation volume that is calculated by the Parkland formula in adults.

C) INCORRECT:

The Holliday-Segar formula may be used to estimate maintenance fluid requirements. However, the fluid requirement of patients with burns during the first 24 hours far exceeds the estimate provided by the Holliday-Segar formula. A different method is therefore required to assess adequate fluid requirement during the first 24 hours.

D) INCORRECT:

Sphygmomanometric blood pressure monitoring in a burned limb is unreliable, as edema of the area does not allow for the accurate auscultation of Korotkoff sounds. Blood pressure is therefore underestimated. If more fluid were administered to the patient based on a misinterpretation of blood pressure, edema in the limb would worsen, and the risk of pulmonary edema would increase. Also, blood pressure may be normal despite decreased intravascular fluid volume and end-organ perfusion in a patient with an intact vasomotor response and would only begin to decrease once shock sets in. Even intraarterial manometry may be unreliable because of peripheral vasoconstriction by stress hormones (e.g., catecholamines).

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) may be increased in patients with burns during the initial 12–18 hours as a result of cardiac dysfunction. However, PCWP should not be used to verify if the infused fluid volume is adequate because PCWP is also not a reliable indicator of end-organ perfusion.

F) INCORRECT:

Central venous pressure (CVP) should not be used to verify the adequacy of fluid volume infusion, since a decrease in CVP is a relatively late sign of intravascular volume depletion in patients with intact vasomotor reflexes. CVP is thus not a reliable measure of end-organ perfusion.

G) CORRECT:

Urine output is a good indicator of kidney perfusion, which is an indicator of overall organ perfusion. Maintaining organ perfusion is the primary goal of IV fluid therapy in burn patients. Initially, the approximate volume of fluid required may be estimated (e.g., based on the total body surface area involved), however, this is merely a starting point, and IV fluid volume should be titrated to maintain a urine output of 0.5 mL/kg/h in adults (1 mL/kg/h in children). Although heart rate and blood pressure should be monitored in patients with burns, these parameters are not good indicators of overall organ perfusion. If urine output falls below 0.5 mL/kg/h, a 500–1000 mL bolus of crystalloid fluid should be given, and the maintenance infusion rate should be increased by 20–30%.
questions.hint: The most important goal of IV fluid resuscitation is to maintain end-organ perfusion while avoiding fluid overload.

questions.text: A previously healthy 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after sustaining an injury to his right hand. His mother says that she was cleaning the bathroom when he accidentally knocked over the drain cleaner bottle and spilled the liquid onto his hand. On arrival, he is crying and holding his right hand in a flexed position. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. Examination of the right hand shows a 4 x 4 cm area of reddened, blistered skin. The area is very tender to light touch. His ability to flex and extend the right hand are diminished. Radial pulses are palpable. Capillary refill time is less than 3 seconds. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Emergency escharotomy is indicated if vascular compromise is suspected (e.g., compartment syndrome), which is especially common in the case of peripheral, circumferential burns with the presence of eschar. Because this patient has good capillary refill and pulses of the affected hand, however, vascular compromise is very unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Wound debridement is performed to promote wound healing and decrease the risk of infection from the necrotic tissue. While this patient may require wound debridement, the offending agent first has to be removed from the skin to prevent further burn progression.

C) INCORRECT:

Mineral oil is the treatment of choice for skin burns caused by elemental metals (e.g., lithium, potassium, sodium, magnesium). These metals cannot be removed through irrigation with water because doing so results in a chemical reaction that would worsen the burn. However, this patient's chemical burn is unlikely to be caused by elemental metals and requires a different intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Silver sulfadiazine is a topical antibiotic that can be considered in cases of severe and/or widespread, full-thickness burns. The absence of eschar in this patient's burn and the fact that it is tender make it more likely that he has a partial-thickness burn. Although he may still require antibiotics eventually, topical antibiotics would not be the most appropriate next step in management.

E) INCORRECT:

Split-thickness skin grafts are typically used in the case of injury affecting large areas of skin. Although this patient may benefit from skin grafting in the future, acute management of a chemical burn requires other interventions first.

F) CORRECT:

Copious irrigation with water is the most appropriate initial step in management for the majority of chemical skin burns. It dilutes and removes the offending agent from the skin. Irrigation should be continued until the pH of the affected tissue has become neutral, which may take several hours in case of alkaline burns.

The only exceptions to this rule are burns caused by elemental metals (e.g., potassium, magnesium) and dry lime. In these cases, adding water can cause a chemical reaction that would worsen the burn; mineral oil should be used instead.
Image Description:

A singular blister on an erythematous base is visible on the back of the hand.

The presence of a blister within the area of erythema differentiates this from a first-degree burn. No deeper tissue injury suggestive of a higher-degree burn is evident, confirming a second-degree burn.
questions.hint: The initial treatment for chemical burns is the same regardless of the chemical's pH.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after spilling hot oil on himself in a kitchen accident. Examination shows multiple tense blisters over the abdomen, anterior chest, and entire right leg. Deroofing of the blisters reveals tender and mottled underlying skin that does not blanch with pressure. Examination of the left thigh shows tender and erythematous skin with quick capillary refill after blanching with pressure. Which of the following is the closest estimate of total body surface area affected by second-degree burns in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Application of the rule of nines estimates 9% of TBSA if only one body segment is affected. Several segments of this patient's body are affected by second-degree burns.

B) INCORRECT:

Application of the rule of nines estimates 18% of TBSA if only two body segments are affected. Several segments of this patient's body are affected by second-degree burns.

C) INCORRECT:

If the injury on this patient's left thigh were a second-degree burn rather than a first-degree burn, application of the rule of nines would estimate 45% of TBSA.

D) INCORRECT:

Application of the rule of nines estimates 72% of TBSA if eight body segments are affected. Fewer segments of this patient's body are affected by second-degree burns.

E) INCORRECT:

Application of the rule of nines estimates 54% of TBSA if six body segments are affected. Fewer segments of this patient's body are affected by second-degree burns.

F) CORRECT:

The rule of nines divides the body into 11 regions (head, anterior chest, abdomen, upper back, lower back, right arm, left arm, right thigh, left thigh, right lower leg, left lower leg), each of which is estimated to be 9% of TBSA. This patient has deep second-degree burns (characterized by blisters and nonblanching underlying skin) on his chest, abdomen, and entire right leg, which corresponds to 36% of TBSA. He also has a first-degree burn on his left thigh.
Image Description:

The entire body surface of an adult can be divided into 11 regions, each comprising approximately 9% of the total body surface area. The external genitalia accounts for the remaining 1%. The rule of nines is used to quickly estimate the total body surface area affected by burns in adults.
questions.hint: This patient has first and second-degree burns. The total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns is estimated using the rule of nines.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department shortly after sustaining injuries in a building fire. On arrival, he appears agitated and has shortness of breath. Examination shows multiple second-degree burns over the chest and abdomen and third-degree burns over the upper extremities. Treatment with intravenous fluids and analgesics is begun. Two days later, the patient is confused. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 125/min, and blood pressure is 100/58 mm Hg. Examination shows violaceous discoloration and edema of the burn wounds. His leukocyte count is 16,000/mm3. Blood cultures grow gram-negative, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting rods. The causal organism actively secretes a virulence factor that acts primarily via which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phagocytosis can be inhibited by the pertussis toxin, which is actively secreted by Bordetella pertussis, a gram-negative, oxidase-positive coccobacillus. B. pertussis causes fever, paroxysmal cough, and posttussive vomiting in unimmunized children but does not infect burn wounds. Components of certain bacteria (e.g., mucoid polysaccharide capsule of Pseudomonas aeruginosa) also inhibit phagocytosis. However, these are structural components that are not actively secreted.

B) INCORRECT:

The overwhelming release of cytokines (e.g., IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α) can be induced by endotoxins from gram-negative bacteria and by superantigens (e.g., TSST-1 of Staphylococcus aureus, erythrogenic exotoxin A of Streptococcus pyogenes). The release of endotoxins from Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is the organism infecting this patient's burns, is most likely responsible for the features of septic shock (hypotension, tachycardia, confusion, leukocytosis). However, endotoxins are released by bacterial cell lysis and are not actively secreted.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluid secretion from cells can be increased by exotoxins that elevate cAMP levels (e.g., heat-labile toxin of enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli, edema toxin of Bacillus anthracis, cholera toxin of Vibrio cholerae). E. coli is a gram-negative rod, and certain strains can infect burn wounds and result in septic shock, as seen here. However, E. coli is also an oxidase-negative, lactose-fermenting organism. Moreover, the exotoxin-producing strains of E. coli (ETEC) typically cause diarrhea and not burn wound infections.

D) CORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa secretes exotoxin A, which inactivates elongation factor-2 (EF-2) by ADP-ribosylation. Since EF-2 facilitates the translocation of the growing peptide from the A site to the P site of eukaryotic ribosomes, deactivation of EF-2 causes inhibition of protein synthesis. P. aeruginosa also produces phospholipase C, which degrades cell membranes. Together, these toxins enable P. aeruginosa to infect burn wounds and cause local necrosis. This patient's features of septic shock (hypotension, tachycardia, confusion, leukocytosis) are most likely caused by the endotoxins produced by P. aeruginosa. However, endotoxins are released by bacterial lysis and are not actively secreted.

The diphtheria toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae also inactivates EF-2. Other exotoxins that inhibit protein synthesis are the Shiga toxin of Shigella spp. and Shiga-like toxin of enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli, which deadenylate the 60S subunit of eukaryotic rRNA.

E) INCORRECT:

The release of neurotransmitters can be inhibited by the Clostridium tetani exotoxin, which inhibits glycine and GABA release, and by the Clostridium botulinum exotoxin, which inhibits acetylcholine release. C. tetani, a non-lactose fermenting rod, often infects burn wounds. This is the rationale for administering the tetanus vaccine or the tetanus immune globulin in patients with burns. However, C. tetani is a gram-positive, oxidase-negative organism that typically causes spastic paralysis, which is not seen here.
questions.hint: Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a gram-negative, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting rod, is an important cause of burn wound infections. A virulence factor that is actively secreted by an organism is called an exotoxin.

questions.text: One week after admission to the hospital for burns sustained in a building fire, a 24-year-old man undergoes evaluation for the feasibility of skin grafting. Physical examination shows third-degree burns on his entire torso, left arm, and head. Urine and blood cultures grow no organisms. A chest x-ray shows no abnormalities. Compared with a healthy adult, which of the following changes are most likely to be seen in this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Increased resting energy expenditure is a typical finding in patients one week after severe thermal injury. Severe burns, as seen in this patient, lead to a hypermetabolic state, which provides energy to the cells involved in wound healing and counters the significant heat and water loss that results from the loss of insulating cutaneous tissue. This postburn hypermetabolic response is characterized by two distinct phases. During the first phase (called the “Ebb phase,” up to 48 hours postburn), cardiac output and metabolism are decreased. The second phase (called the “flow phase”) is characterized by an increase in stress-induced hormones (e.g., catecholamines, glucocorticoids) and inflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF-α), which lead to a gradual increase in metabolism, cardiac output, and body temperature until reaching a plateau (around one week postburn). Consequences of the hypermetabolic response include hyperglycemia, peripheral insulin resistance, increased muscle protein degradation, increased lipolysis, and significant weight loss.

Postburn hypermetabolism can last up to 2–3 years and is associated with poor long-term results (e.g., immune dysfunction and infections, delayed wound healing). Therapeutic strategies to alter this response include early excision of necrotic tissue and skin grafting, thermoregulation, early enteral feeding with a high-carbohydrate, high-protein diet, glycemic control, beta blockers, anabolic steroids, pain management, and supportive psychotherapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitrogen balance represents the difference between nitrogen intake and nitrogen loss and depends on the level of intake and breakdown of amino acids in proteins. In patients one week after severe thermal injury, nitrogen balance is typically decreased, not increased, which is a result of increased proteolysis induced by inflammatory cytokines and stress hormones.

C) INCORRECT:

Peripheral lipolysis in patients one week after severe thermal injury is typically increased, not decreased, secondary to the release of catecholamines and other stress hormones that promote lipid degradation.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroid secretion in patients one week after severe thermal injury is typically increased, not decreased, as extensive burns lead to a hypermetabolic response that induces the secretion of stress hormones.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac output in patients one week after severe thermal injury is typically increased, not decreased, most likely due to the increased release of stress hormones, which increase cardiac output.
questions.hint: This change would also be seen in patients with hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a coworker 2 hours after accidentally burning his foot on an electric grill that he keeps next to his bed because he likes to wake up to the smell of bacon. He initially decided to go to work despite his injury but felt like it was “too serious to ignore.” He is the regional manager of a paper company. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of his right foot shows erythematous skin with multiple blisters, some of which have ruptured. The affected skin is tender to light touch. Which of the following best describes this patient's skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythema, pain, and skin that blanches when pressure is applied may be seen in superficial burns (i.e., first-degree burns). This type of burn, however, does not typically cause blisters and the skin is typically dry and does not weep. First-degree burns only involve the epidermis and heal within 3–6 days without scarring.
Image Description:

Upper body of a patient with moderate sunburn

Patches of erythema are visible across the areas of skin that were most exposed to the sun. The absence of blisters distinguishes this presentation from a second-degree burn (partial-thickness burn).

Sunburn most commonly manifests as a first-degree burn, but higher-degree burns are possible with prolonged sun exposure.

B) CORRECT:

Pain, erythema (blanching), and blisters that may rupture (to reveal the moist and weeping skin beneath) are consistent with a superficial partial-thickness burn (i.e., a superficial second-degree burn). This type of burn affects the entire thickness of the epidermis and the upper layers of the dermis but spares deep dermal appendages, such as hair follicles, sweat glands, and sebaceous glands. Nociceptive nerve endings are intact and the affected areas are extremely tender. Superficial partial-thickness burns heal within 1–3 weeks and lead to hypo/hyperpigmentation but no scarring (see “Overview of burn depth” table).
Image Description:

A singular blister on an erythematous base is visible on the back of the hand.

The presence of a blister within the area of erythema differentiates this from a first-degree burn. No deeper tissue injury suggestive of a higher-degree burn is evident, confirming a second-degree burn.

C) INCORRECT:

Erythema and blisters may be seen in deep partial-thickness burns (i.e., deep second-degree burns). This type of burn is minimally painful, however, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation. Deep second-degree burns are dry and do not blanch when pressure is applied. They extend from the epidermis to the deeper dermis, and they also damage surrounding deep dermal appendages and nociceptive nerve endings, which is why affected areas only perceive pressure but no pain. Healing takes 3 weeks or longer and results in scar formation.
Image Description:

Back and gluteal region

A large burned area with many vesicles and multiple large, fragile bullae (partially ruptured or deroofed) is visible.

The presence of blistering differentiates this from a first-degree burn. Wound bases appear to extend into deeper layers of the dermis than would be expected with a superficial partial-thickness burn (especially where blisters have been deroofed). There is no obvious tissue necrosis or eschar formation, differentiating this from higher-degree burns.

D) INCORRECT:

Full-thickness burns (i.e., third-degree burns) typically do not blister or blanch and are painless, nonerythematous, dry, and associated with tissue necrosis with black, white, or gray leathery skin/eschar, all of which are inconsistent with this patient's presentation. This type of burn extends through the entire dermis and part of the subcutaneous tissue, sparing deeper structures (i.e., muscles, fat, fascia, bones). Third-degree burns do not heal by themselves and have to be managed with early debridement of necrotic tissue, soft skin reconstruction (i.e., grafts, flaps), and antibiotics.
Image Description:

Photograph of the chest and right shoulder

The skin appears dry, leathery, and black, indicating tissue necrosis (eschar). There is no visible blistering.

These features are characteristic of a third-degree burn, which affects all the layers of the skin (i.e., the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue).

E) INCORRECT:

Deeper injury burns (i.e., fourth-degree burns) typically do not blister or blanch and are painless, nonerythematous, and appear white, dry, or charred, all of which are inconsistent with this patient's presentation. This type of burn extends beyond the entire subcutaneous layer of the skin and involves deeper structures such as muscles, fat, fascia, and bone. Management involves amputation or extensive removal of dead tissue.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left hand

There are deep burn injuries visible across all digits, with charred black tissue and exposed bone and tendon. Second-degree burns are present on the palmar skin, indicated by erythema, vesicles, and blistering.
questions.hint: When the coworker, who is the Assistant to the Regional Manager at Dunder Mifflin, applies pressure on the patient's foot, the burn wound blanches and refills quickly.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after she was rescued from a burning apartment. She was trapped in the apartment for about 20 minutes. On arrival, the patient is awake but confused. She has a Glasgow Coma Score of 12. Her pulse is 116/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 104/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination shows multiple partial-thickness burns over the chest, back, and bilateral upper extremities, and full-thickness burns over the face. There is singeing of her nasal hair and eyebrows. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The most appropriate next step in management is to decrease this patient's risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning often occurs in patients exposed to smoke in trapped rooms and is commonly associated with inhalation injury (which this patient has). CO poisoning may manifest with nonspecific symptoms, such as confusion, and cannot be ruled out by standard pulse oximetry. Although testing with CO-oximetry and early administration of 100% oxygen is recommended for patients with suspected CO poisoning, another step in management is more urgently needed here.

B) INCORRECT:

Stress ulcers that occur as a complication of severe burn injuries are also called Curling ulcers. Although stress ulcer prophylaxis should be considered in any critically ill patient with a risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, ulceration of the gastric mucosa usually begins several hours after the initial insult (e.g., trauma, burn injury). Moreover, this patient has no clinical features suggesting a stress ulcer, such as hypotension or shock, hematemesis, and melena. Instead, a more acutely life-threatening condition should be addressed first.

C) INCORRECT:

Disseminated bacterial infection is a possible complication of burn injuries, as burn wounds are often colonized by multiple pathogens (e.g., MRSA, Pseudomonas). In addition, prolonged exposure to smoke (e.g., due to entrapment in closed spaces) causes ciliary dysfunction, which decreases the clearance of airway secretions and increases the risk of bacterial pneumonia. This patient's burns involve > 30% of the body surface, which can lead to immunosuppression, increasing her risk of developing an infection. However, a bacterial infection is unlikely to occur in the first several hours after the incident. Though topical antibiotics should be applied to all nonsuperficial burns to prevent wound infection, another step in management is more urgently needed.

D) INCORRECT:

Volume overload from over-resuscitation with fluids can lead to serious complications (e.g., pleural effusions, compartment syndrome). The ATLS and American Burn Association now recommend only giving half of the 24-hour fluid resuscitation volume that is calculated by the Parkland formula, i.e., 2 mL x BW x %BSA instead of 4 mL x BW x %BSA (BW is body weight in kg; %BSA is the percentage of body surface area involved in 2nd- and 3rd-degree burns). Although fluids should be administered prudently, the patient likely has a volume deficit, not an overload, at this point. To avoid complications of under-resuscitation (e.g., acute kidney injury), fluid replacement with crystalloids should be initiated.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's full-thickness burns over the face and singed nasal hair and eyebrows after being trapped in a burning apartment likely indicate thermal inhalation injury. Burn-related injury of the airways (often in combination with fluid resuscitation) can lead to the rapid development of upper airway edema and obstruction. Therefore, immediate intubation is necessary if inhalation injury is suspected or if burns involve more than 30–40% of the body surface, as seen here. Although this patient currently has no signs of impending respiratory decompensation (e.g., severe hypoxia, tachypnea) and only a mildly altered level of consciousness (GCS of 12), intubation and mechanical ventilation are the most appropriate next steps to prevent sudden airway obstruction and respiratory failure.
questions.hint: Treat first what kills first.

questions.text:
Six days after being admitted to the intensive care unit for partial-thickness burns involving 36% of the body surface area, a 30-year-old woman develops decreased urine output. She sustained burns after spilling boiling hot water on herself while cooking. She was admitted for fluid resuscitation, nutritional support, pain management, and wound care; she was doing well until today. She is receiving total parenteral nutrition via a central venous catheter. She has no other medical conditions. She is oriented to person only. Her temperature is 35.1°C (95.2°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 31/min, blood pressure is 96/59 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 93% on 5 L oxygen/min via face mask. Examination shows extensive partial-thickness burns across her lower abdomen and legs and some full-thickness burns. The lesions are tender and have violaceous and edematous borders. The skin around the central venous catheter site appears normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12 g/dL


Leukocyte count
18,000/mm3


Platelet count
150,000/mm3



Arterial blood gas analysis shows:


pH
7.28


PCO2

35 mm Hg


PO2

68 mm Hg


HCO3-

16 mEq/L


Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's worsening symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A bleeding stress ulcer can manifest with features of hypovolemic shock, such as hypotension, tachycardia, oliguria, tachypnea, metabolic acidosis, and altered mental status, all of which are seen here. In addition, severe burns are a risk factor for Curling ulcers. However, patients with a bleeding stress ulcer typically present with hematemesis, melena, and/or anemia, none of which this patient has. Moreover, leukocytosis, hypothermia, and tender burn wounds with edematous borders would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI) may arise from volume depletion in severe burns and can manifest with oliguria, metabolic acidosis, and altered mental status (e.g., due to uremia). Although this patient most likely has prerenal AKI as a complication of her condition, leukocytosis, hypothermia, and tender burn wounds with edematous and violaceous borders suggest a different underlying cause of this patient's worsening symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

Leukocytosis, hypothermia, and tender burn wounds with violaceous and edematous borders in conjunction with organ dysfunction and hypotension are suggestive of septic shock. Patients with burns have an increased risk of infection and subsequent bacteremia due to impaired barrier function of the skin and immunosuppression; the risk increases with the severity of the burn and the amount of body surface area involved. In addition, this patient's burn consists of necrotic tissue, which is a protein-rich media that encourages bacterial growth. Pseudomonas and Staphylococcus are the most common organisms associated with sepsis in hospitalized burn patients, and broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage should be initiated.

D) INCORRECT:

Postburn hypermetabolism is a ubiquitous response to a severe burn injury and can manifest with tachycardia and tachypnea during the hypermetabolic phase 5–7 days following the injury. However, hypertension (due to hyperdynamic circulation) and hyperthermia are expected findings. This patient's leukocytosis and tender burn wounds with edematous borders suggest a different cause of her worsening symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Crush syndrome can manifest with signs of hypovolemia (hypotension, tachycardia, oliguria), tachypnea, and metabolic acidosis, all of which are seen here. Although severe burns can cause rhabdomyolysis resulting in crush syndrome, this syndrome typically occurs in patients with trauma and is, therefore, unlikely given the mechanism of injury here (i.e., burns caused by boiling hot water). In addition, darkened urine and extreme pain in the affected region are typical features of crush syndrome. Hypothermia, leukocytosis, and tender burn wounds with edematous borders suggest a different cause of this patient's worsening symptoms.
questions.hint: Oliguria, altered mental status, hypotension, tachycardia, hypoxemic respiratory failure, and metabolic acidosis in a patient with burns are features of multiple organ dysfunction.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a propane tank explosion in his van while he was preparing a meal. Two runners had found him outside of his vehicle with his shirt and pants on fire. On arrival, he is alert and fully oriented. He has no history of serious illness and his only medication is a multivitamin. He is a retired banker who currently works as a surfing instructor. He appears to be in moderate distress. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/67 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Examination shows nonblanching gray leathery skin across the surfaces of the anterior arms, anterior thighs, and the anterior right lower leg. On neurologic examination, sensation to pinprick is absent over the affected areas. Perception of deep pressure is intact. Pedal and radial pulses are palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Debridement of necrotic tissue and hydrocolloid dressing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Early debridement of burnt necrotic tissue is indicated for full-thickness burns, and hydrocolloid dressings are used for partial thickness burns and smaller wounds. However, initial management of patients with moderate to major burns should prioritize trauma resuscitation (i.e., ABCDEs).

B) INCORRECT:

Initial management of patients with moderate to major burns (e.g., full-thickness burns involving > 20% TBSA) should prioritize trauma resuscitation (i.e., ABCDEs). If needed, high-flow oxygen therapy should not be delayed because fluid resuscitation can increase laryngeal swelling, complicating intubation. High-flow oxygen therapy is only indicated if inhalation injury is suspected and/or if burns involve > 30% TBSA, whereas this patient's burns are less extensive.

C) CORRECT:

Urgent fluid resuscitation is indicated in patients with major burns. Patients with partial and full-thickness burns affecting > 20% TBSA are at increased risk of shock and require intravenous fluids to ensure sufficient organ and tissue perfusion. In patients with major burns, cytokine release causes increased vascular permeability and loss of intravascular volume leading to significant third spacing of fluid. Initial therapy with lactated Ringer solution is preferred because normal saline can cause hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. The volume for fluid therapy during the first 24 hours can be calculated using different formulas (e.g., modified Parkland formula). After they are stabilized, patients who require aggressive fluid resuscitation should undergo urethral catheterization to monitor urine output and adjust fluids. Fluid therapy should be modified to achieve urine output of 0.5 mL/kg/h in adult patients.

Initial evaluation and treatment of patients with moderate to major burns should follow the ABCDE approach used for critically ill or injured patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Although topical antibiotic therapy is indicated in patients with full-thickness and deeper-injury burns, prophylactic systemic antibiotic therapy is not routinely recommended. Systemic antibiotic therapy (e.g., vancomycin) is only indicated for burn wound infection or sepsis, neither of which is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Thromboprophylaxis (e.g., low molecular weight heparin) is indicated in patients with moderate to major burns (e.g., full-thickness burns affecting > 20% TBSA) because of the increased risk of venous thromboembolism. However, initial management should prioritize trauma resuscitation (i.e., ABCDEs).
questions.hint: This patient presents with third-degree burns affecting ∼ 22.5% of his total body surface area (TBSA). This is estimated with the rule of nines: anterior thighs (9%) + anterior arms (9%) + anterior right lower leg (4.5%).

questions.text:
A fully vaccinated 7-year-old boy with no chronic medical conditions presents to the emergency department shortly after accidentally knocking over a pot of boiling water on himself at home.
He is alert and anxious but cooperative. His temperature is 37.3°C, his heart rate is 122 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and his blood pressure is 104/60 mm Hg.
He has moist, red, weeping skin with scattered overlying intact bullae covering the dorsum of his left forearm to the elbow and a few dry red patches on the back of the left hand and the left upper arm, all of which blanch with pressure. All erythematous areas are very tender to light palpation. His pulses, sensation, and capillary refill distal to the injury in the left hand are normal. There are no circumferential burns or linear, demarcated patterns. He has full active range of motion in his left wrist and all fingers, although movement of his left arm is very painful. You clear the case with the social worker on call for the emergency department.
What management is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital for observation, fluid rehydration, and intravenous antibiotics
Discharge with a prescription for oral pain medication after covering the left forearm with nonadherent dressing
Discharge after applying a nonadherent dressing to the left forearm with prescriptions for an oral pain medication and a 10-day course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
Discharge after applying petroleum jelly, prescribing an oral pain medication, and providing instructions to leave the wound open to the air
Administer warm intravenous fluids and transfer or admit to the nearest burn center

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If there was evidence of a full-thickness burn — or a partial-thickness burn involving the face, hands, perineum, eyes, or ≥5% of TBSA or with circumferential element — the patient might require admission for intravenous fluids, pain control, surgical consultation, and possible transfer to the nearest burn center. Systemic antibiotics (oral or intravenous) are not required for the management of mild-to-moderate burns.

B) CORRECT:

Superficial (first-degree) burns have a dry, red appearance, blanch with pressure, and are painful to palpation. Superficial partial-thickness (second-degree) burns are moist, red, and weeping, may have blisters, and are very painful to palpation and air movement. Deep partial-thickness burns do not blanch, and perception is limited to pressure only. Full-thickness (third-degree) burns are waxy and leathery, and perception is limited to deep pressure.

This patient has a superficial partial-thickness (second-degree) burn covering the dorsum of the forearm, which makes up approximately 2% of total body-surface area (TBSA) as well as scattered superficial (first-degree) burns on his left hand and upper arm. Because the partial-thickness burn covers <5% of TBSA, does not involve the face or hands, and has no circumferential element, it is considered a minor burn.

Nonaccidental trauma should always be considered when evaluating burn injuries in young children. Scalding burns that are intentional typically have a sharp area of demarcation, are located posteriorly, and do not have splash marks (as this patient does). If there is any concern for nonaccidental trauma, social work should be consulted before discharge.

Tetanus vaccination status should be confirmed for all burn patients. The optimal regimen for tetanus prophylaxis depends on the patient’s vaccination history and on whether the current wound is clean or dirty.

Key learning point: The type of dressing that is recommended for a partial-thickness burn is a nonadherent dressing.

C) INCORRECT:

The optimal management for a minor burn involves cleaning the affected area with 0.1% chlorhexidine, sterile water, or sterile saline; applying a nonadherent dressing; providing oral pain management; and conducting close follow-up. Systemic antibiotics (oral or intravenous) are not required for the management of mild-to-moderate burns.

D) INCORRECT:

Petroleum jelly alone with no overlying dressing or protection against the development of infection is not sufficient for partial-thickness burns.

E) INCORRECT:

If there was evidence of a full-thickness burn — or a partial-thickness burn involving the face, hands, perineum, eyes, or ≥5% of TBSA or with circumferential element — the patient might require admission for intravenous fluids, pain control, surgical consultation, and possible transfer to the nearest burn center.

questions.text:
A fully vaccinated 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after he inadvertently pulled a pot of boiling water onto himself. He jumped out of the way as the pot fell to the floor and was splashed with boiling water on his right hand and wrist, but he was otherwise unharmed. He cried initially, and his parents gave him one dose of acetaminophen, but he is still in pain.
He has normal vital signs. Examination of the 4-cm x 2-cm burn area reveals a pink, moist surface with an overlying blister (figure). The area blanches with pressure.
In addition to pain control, what is the best next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Clean the exposed skin thoroughly, and cover with a nonadherent dressing
Administer a single dose of ampicillin-sulbactam intravenously, then irrigate with saline, and debride and dress the wound
Admit to the hospital for observation with intravenous hydration and ampicillin-sulbactam
Irrigate with saline, then debride and dress the wound
Apply topical silver sulfadiazine and barrier ointment, dress the wound, and discharge with a 10-day course of oral antibiotics

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The therapeutic management and associated morbidity of burn injuries are largely determined by the depth and healing potential of the burn. First-degree burns are superficial, dry, and painful, and they heal in less than 7 to 10 days.

Second-degree burns are partial-thickness burns but can be superficial or deep.
• Superficial partial-thickness burns extend into the superficial dermis and are generally pink or red with clear blisters and a moist surface. They blanch with pressure.
• Deep partial-thickness burns have yellow or white coloring, are somewhat dry, and blanch less, although blistering may still be seen.

Full-thickness (third- and fourth-degree) burns extend through the entire dermis and into underlying tissues to varying degrees. Full-thickness burns are often black or white, charred, dry, and nonblanching. These deeper burns are associated with longer healing times and complications such as scarring, contractures, and functional impairment.

This patient has superficial partial-thickness burns. The most appropriate management is to provide analgesia; clean the burn area with 0.1% chlorhexidine, mild soap and water, or saline; and apply a semisynthetic dressing.

Tetanus vaccination status should be confirmed for all burn patients. The optimal regimen for tetanus prophylaxis depends on the patient’s vaccination history and on whether the current wound is clean or dirty.

Key learning point: A burn that is red or pink, has a moist surface with blisters, and blanches with pressure is most likely to be a superficial partial-thickness (second-degree) burn.

B) INCORRECT:

The prophylactic use of systemic antibiotics is not indicated in uncomplicated minor burns. Blisters that are intact and appear clean are generally not debrided; debridement may be considered when the blisters are large around joint spaces, appear likely to rupture, or are possibly infected or when there is concern for more severe underlying burn injury that needs to be fully assessed.

C) INCORRECT:

Hospitalization and prophylactic use of systemic antibiotics are not indicated in uncomplicated minor burns.

D) INCORRECT:

Blisters that are intact and appear clean are generally not debrided; debridement may be considered when the blisters are large around joint spaces, appear likely to rupture, or are possibly infected or when there is concern for more severe underlying burn injury that needs to be fully assessed.

E) INCORRECT:

In a meta-analysis, silver sulfadiazine was associated with poorer wound healing than semisynthetic dressings, and no particular dressing was shown to be superior to the others. The prophylactic use of systemic antibiotics is not indicated in uncomplicated minor burns.

questions.text:
A 15-month-old boy weighing 10 kg presents to the emergency department (ED) shortly after pulling a pot of boiling water from the stove onto his body. His parents immediately removed as much of his clothing as possible and ran cool water over his burned skin before bringing him to the ED.
His vital signs are notable for tachycardia. Physical examination reveals blistering scald burns to the chest, abdomen, and both arms, which you estimate to be 25% of the patient’s total body-surface area. Morphine is given, and the patient is started on a maintenance rate of intravenous fluids with 5% dextrose in normal saline.
In addition to continuing maintenance intravenous fluids, what is the most appropriate additional management in the first 8 hours of this patient’s care?

choices.text: Infusion of 42 mL/hour of normal saline
Infusion of 62 mL/hour of lactated Ringer solution

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skin grafting is sometimes indicated for deep partial-thickness and full-thickness (third- and fourth-degree) burns, but it is typically done a few days to a few weeks after the burn, depending on how severe the burn is and how well the skin is healing on its own. Fluid resuscitation takes more immediate precedence when a large TBSA burn has occurred.

B) INCORRECT:

Although burns are at high risk for infection, systemic antibiotics should be used only when there is clinical concern for infection. Prophylactic systemic antibiotic treatment has not been shown to improve outcomes in burn patients.

C) INCORRECT:

The most commonly used formula for estimating resuscitation fluid requirements in children is the Parkland formula: 4 mL/kg × body weight (in kg) × % TBSA. In this case, the patient’s total need for resuscitation fluid is calculated as follows: 4 mL/kg × 10 kg × 25 = 1000 mL. Thus, 500 mL of crystalloid solution, such as lactated Ringer solution (preferred by most burn centers), should be given in the first 8 hours (or about 62 mL/hr), and 500 mL should be given in the subsequent 16 hours (or about 31 mL/hr).

D) CORRECT:

Calculating the total body-surface area (TBSA) of a burn is critical to determining management. Superficial partial-thickness (second-degree) burns should be included in the calculation, but superficial (first-degree) burns should not; blistering is a helpful indicator to distinguish between these two types of burns. The Lund-Browder chart is the most accurate method of estimating TBSA in children and adults. For adults, the rule of nines can also be used (whereby the head represents 9% of TBSA, each arm 9%, each leg 18%, and the anterior and posterior trunk each 18%). Small burn areas can also be approximated using the patients’ palms — the palmar surface, excluding the fingers, is approximately 0.5% TBSA; the entire palmar surface, including fingers, is approximately 1% TBSA.

For patients with severe burns covering at least 20% of TBSA (as in this case), the most important elements of initial management are respiratory support (if needed), pain management, and aggressive fluid resuscitation. In children with burns, resuscitative fluids are required in addition to maintenance fluids. The most commonly used formula for estimating resuscitation fluid requirements in children is the Parkland formula:

4 mL/kg × body weight (in kg) × % TBSA

The first half of the total resuscitative fluid should be given in the first 8 hours of care and the remaining half in the subsequent 16 hours. In this case, the patient’s total need for resuscitation fluid is calculated as follows: 4 mL/kg × 10 kg × 25 = 1000 mL. Thus, 500 mL of crystalloid solution, such as lactated Ringer solution (preferred by most burn centers), should be given in the first 8 hours (or about 62 mL/hr), and 500 mL should be given in the subsequent 16 hours (or about 31 mL/hr).

Notably, although resuscitation formulas are useful in determining intravenous fluid initiation rates, the resuscitation rate should ultimately be titrated to the target urine output, which is typically 1 to 2 mL/kg/hr in children. Under-resuscitation can cause shock, suboptimal tissue perfusion, end-organ failure, and death. In contrast, over-resuscitation can cause compartment syndrome and pulmonary edema, with potentially unnecessary tracheostomy placement.

Infants and young children (especially under 5 years of age) are at increased risk for hypoglycemia after a burn because of the rapid depletion of limited glycogen stores in the setting of elevated glucocorticoid and catecholamine levels. Infants and young children should therefore receive fluids containing 5% dextrose at maintenance rate, with monitoring of blood glucose levels, in addition to resuscitation intravenous fluid. For children 5 years of age or older, non-dextrose-containing maintenance fluids may be started instead.

Of note, this patient also meets criteria for transfer to a specialized burn-treatment center if he is not currently at one. Criteria for consultation with and/or transfer to a burn center include:

• Any full-thickness burns
• Partial-thickness burns covering >10% of TBSA
• Deep or partial-thickness burns involving the genitalia, feet, perineum, or joints
• Concomitant traumatic or inhalation injuries
• Poorly controlled pain

Key learning point: For patients with severe burns covering at least 20% of their total body-surface area (TBSA), the most important elements of initial management are respiratory support (if needed), pain management, and aggressive fluid resuscitation calculated on the basis of the TBSA of the burn.

E) INCORRECT:

Burns related to fire should raise concern for possible cyanide poisoning, which can be rapidly lethal. Treatment includes administration of hydroxocobalamin, which binds cyanide. This patient’s burns were caused by boiling water, not a fire, so he is not at risk for cyanide poisoning.

questions.text: A 28-year-old soldier is brought back to a military treatment facility 45 minutes after sustaining injuries in a building fire from a mortar attack. He was trapped inside the building for around 20 minutes. On arrival, he is confused and appears uncomfortable. He has a Glasgow coma score (GCS) of 13. His pulse is 113/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows multiple partial-thickness burns over the chest and bilateral upper extremities and full-thickness burns over the face. There are black sediments seen within the nose and mouth. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Though topical antibiotics should be applied to all nonsuperficial burns to prevent wound infection, prophylactic systemic antibiotic therapy has no proven benefit in treating patients with burn injuries. Intravenous antibiotics are only indicated later in the course of injury if there is a strong suspicion for sepsis and/or wound infection.

B) CORRECT:

Thermal inhalation injury (often in combination with fluid resuscitation) can lead to the rapid development of upper airway edema and obstruction. Even though this patient currently has no signs of impending respiratory decompensation (e.g., hypoxia, tachypnea) and only a mildly altered level of consciousness (GCS of 13), if inhalation injury is suspected or burns involve more than 30–40% of the body surface, intubation and mechanical ventilation should be carried out to prevent sudden airway obstruction and respiratory failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Fiberoptic bronchoscopy can be used to confirm the diagnosis of thermal inhalation injury, as well as to aid in complicated intubation. Because intubation has not been attempted and there are no signs suggesting difficult intubation (e.g., stridor, severe neck burns), this invasive procedure is not indicated at this time. In the case of thermal inhalation injury, bronchoscopy may demonstrate erythema and grayish-white discoloration of the respiratory tract (due to soot).

D) INCORRECT:

Dressing and bandaging of wounds are indicated in the definitive management of partial-thickness burns. Although this patient presents with multiple partial-thickness burns, wound care is not the most appropriate next step in management given the high suspicion for thermal inhalation injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy can be administered to patients with severe carbon monoxide poisoning (e.g., CNS or cardiac involvement, poor responders to normal oxygen therapy). Unlike this patient, patients with carbon monoxide poisoning typically present with confusion, somnolence, agitation, headache, nausea, and, occasionally, a cherry-red skin tone. Although carbon monoxide poisoning often occurs in conjunction with thermal inhalation injury, hyperbaric oxygen therapy is not indicated without confirmation of this diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient, who was trapped in a burning building for an extended period of time, has severe burns and soot within his nose and mouth. Burn-related injury of the airways is likely and requires immediate action.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a coworker 2 hours after accidentally burning his foot on an electric grill that he keeps next to his bed because he likes to wake up to the smell of bacon. He initially decided to go to work despite his injury but felt like it was “too serious to ignore.” He is the regional manager of a paper company. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of his right foot shows erythematous skin with multiple blisters, some of which have ruptured. The affected skin is tender to light touch. Which of the following best describes this patient's skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythema, pain, and skin that blanches when pressure is applied may be seen in superficial burns (i.e., first-degree burns). This type of burn, however, does not typically cause blisters and the skin is typically dry and does not weep. First-degree burns only involve the epidermis and heal within 3–6 days without scarring.
Image Description:

Upper body of a patient with moderate sunburn

Patches of erythema are visible across the areas of skin that were most exposed to the sun. The absence of blisters distinguishes this presentation from a second-degree burn (partial-thickness burn).

Sunburn most commonly manifests as a first-degree burn, but higher-degree burns are possible with prolonged sun exposure.

B) CORRECT:

Pain, erythema (blanching), and blisters that may rupture (to reveal the moist and weeping skin beneath) are consistent with a superficial partial-thickness burn (i.e., a superficial second-degree burn). This type of burn affects the entire thickness of the epidermis and the upper layers of the dermis but spares deep dermal appendages, such as hair follicles, sweat glands, and sebaceous glands. Nociceptive nerve endings are intact and the affected areas are extremely tender. questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the office because of pain and redness on his back for 2 days. He returned yesterday from a vacation to East Africa with his parents, where he took multiple rides on hot air balloons. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a tender, nonpruritic, erythematous rash with edema covering the extensor surface of both forearms, the shoulders, and the upper back, with small patches of skin exfoliation. The rash becomes pale when pressed and then rapidly regains color. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wound dressing is indicated for open burns (i.e., partial-thickness or full-thickness burns) because they entail damage to the entire epidermal layer. In these cases, the ability of the skin to retain fluid is lost, making it prone to drying, which impairs wound healing and increases the risk of dehydration. This patient has no open burns, so dressing is not recommended.

This patient has 1st-degree burns, which do not expose the dermis; debridement is unnecessary. In addition, because the dermis is intact, the burn will resolve on its own without scarring.

Topical antimicrobial prophylaxis (e.g., mupirocin) is indicated for deep partial-thickness burns and full-thickness burns. This patient has a 1st-degree burn (with an intact epidermal barrier that protects against infection), which does not require antimicrobial prophylaxis.

questions.text: A fully vaccinated 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after he inadvertently pulled a pot of boiling water onto himself. He jumped out of the way as the pot fell to the floor and was splashed with boiling water on his right hand and wrist, but he was otherwise unharmed. He cried initially, and his parents gave him one dose of acetaminophen, but he is still in pain. He has normal vital signs. Examination of the 4-cm x 2-cm burn area reveals a pink, moist surface with an overlying blister (figure). The area blanches with pressure. In addition to pain control, what is the best next step in this patient’s care?

Admit to the hospital for observation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after she was rescued from a burning apartment. She was trapped in the apartment for about 20 minutes. The patient is awake but confused. She has a Glasgow Coma Score of 12. Her pulse is 116/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 104/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination shows multiple partial-thickness burns over the chest, back, and bilateral upper extremities, and full-thickness burns over the face. There is singeing of her nasal hair and eyebrows. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The most appropriate next step in management is to decrease this patient's risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning often occurs in patients exposed to smoke in trapped rooms and is commonly associated with inhalation injury (which this patient has). CO poisoning may manifest with nonspecific symptoms, such as confusion, and cannot be ruled out by standard pulse oximetry. Although testing with CO-oximetry and early administration of 100% oxygen is recommended for patients with suspected CO poisoning, another step in management is more urgently needed here.

B) INCORRECT:

Stress ulcers that occur as a complication of severe burn injuries are also called Curling ulcers. Although stress ulcer prophylaxis should be considered in any critically ill patient with a risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, ulceration of the gastric mucosa usually begins several hours after the initial insult (e.g., trauma, burn injury). Moreover, this patient has no clinical features suggesting a stress ulcer, such as hypotension or shock, hematemesis, and melena. Instead, a more acutely life-threatening condition should be addressed first.

C) INCORRECT:

Disseminated bacterial infection is a possible complication of burn injuries, as burn wounds are often colonized by multiple pathogens (e.g., MRSA, Pseudomonas). In addition, prolonged exposure to smoke (e.g., due to entrapment in closed spaces) causes ciliary dysfunction, which decreases the clearance of airway secretions and increases the risk of bacterial pneumonia. This patient's burns involve > 30% of the body surface, which can lead to immunosuppression, increasing her risk of developing an infection. However, a bacterial infection is unlikely to occur in the first several hours after the incident. Though topical antibiotics should be applied to all nonsuperficial burns to prevent wound infection, another step in management is more urgently needed.

Volume overload from over-resuscitation with fluids can lead to serious complications (e.g., pleural effusions, compartment syndrome). The ATLS and American Burn Association now recommend only giving half of the 24-hour fluid resuscitation volume that is calculated by the Parkland formula, i.e., 2 mL x BW x %BSA instead of 4 mL x BW x %BSA (BW is body weight in kg; %BSA is the percentage of body surface area involved in 2nd- and 3rd-degree burns). Although fluids should be administered prudently, the patient likely has a volume deficit, not an overload, at this point. To avoid complications of under-resuscitation (e.g., acute kidney injury), fluid replacement with crystalloids should be initiated.

This patient's full-thickness burns over the face and singed nasal hair and eyebrows after being trapped in a burning apartment likely indicate thermal inhalation injury. Serial arterial blood gas analysis is indicated in burn patients if inhalation injury is suspected. Ampicillin (or any other systemic antibiotic) is currently not recommended for prophylaxis of infections in burn patients because of a lack of supporting evidence. Her circumferential burn may impair blood flow to the limb secondary to a loss of skin elasticity (due to a developing eschar) or result in compartment syndrome (caused by an accumulation of fluids) during the healing process.
